Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Real-Time Control of Production Systems for Energy-Efficient Manufacturing: Theory and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to develop a theory for quantitative analysis of energy consumption in production systems; to use the theory for the development of real-time feedback controllers of machine startup/shutdown and preventive maintenance schedule to ensure desired productivity with minimal energy consumption; and to apply the results on the factory floor at General Motors manufacturing plants. Specifically, the problems of performance analysis, bottleneck identification, optimal control and applications will be investigated for production systems with controlled startup/shutdown and preventive maintenance. The approach of the research will be based on analytical studies for systems that are characterized by Markov processes, and numerical experiments for non-Markovian systems. The outcomes of this research will be integrated models of productivity and energy performance for production systems, measurement-based energy bottleneck indicators and algorithms for real-time feedback controllers of machine startup/shutdown and preventive maintenance schedules that minimize energy consumption under desired throughput.

If successful, the results of the research will establish a novel analytical framework for integrated analysis of productivity and energy performance in manufacturing systems. In addition, the results will provide a solid foundation for an integrated study of cost, productivity and energy consumption. This research will provide production floor managers and production systems designers with rigorous, quantitative engineering tools for analysis, improvement, and design of energy-efficient manufacturing systems to ensure desired productivity and environmental performance. This will lead to increased profitability and sustainability for the manufacturing enterprises. Finally, the methodology is also transformable to other systems with variability and resource consumption issues, such as healthcare delivery, transportation, and communication networks, etc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manufacturing is one of the few sources to generate national wealth. In recent years, improving energy efficiency has become one of the primary objectives of manufacturing enterprises, along with increasing productivity and quality. While it is possible to achieve this by upgrading the vast fleet of energy-intensive equipment on the factory floor with efficient ones, it typically requires a great amount of initial investment and pay-back period is usually very long. As studies suggest, production control is one of the most economical ways to improve energy efficiency of manufacturing processes. This provide an opportunity for the factory floor operators and managers to reshape the energy bills of their system without heavy capital investment. To take advantage of this opportunity, the most critical thing is to carefully plan, operate, and control the manufacturing activities to eliminate waste. This, apparently, cannot be simply done by just using intuition and commonsense. Solid understanding of the underlying manufacturing process and justified engineering methods are necessary in this regard. In this NSF supported project “GOALI: Real-Time Control of Production Systems for Energy-Efficient Manufacturing: Theory and Applications,” academic researchers teamed up with industrial professionals to investigation practical and science-supported methods to advance the practice of energy-efficient manufacturing.

Since production control adjustments are carried out in real time by the operators and engineers as soon as a problem is spotted, the first problem is to study the dynamic behavior of a manufacturing process. This is called "transient analysis." Transient analysis is much more complicated than its counterpart - "steady state analysis," which focuses on long-term stationary system performance. In this project, the investigators developed a number of computationally efficient algorithms that can predict the future evolution of key performance indices (KPIs) in manufacturing (e.g., throughput rate, work-in-process level) for any time horizon. On one hand, these algorithms provide useful tools for the manufacturing practitioners to assess the status of their manufacturing systems. On the other hand, the prediction power brought by these algorithms forms a solid foundation to further seek potential improvements over the current operation.

Indeed, the performance prediction algorithms enable us to evaluate the consequence of a production control action before it is actually implemented. From the energy efficiency improvement perspective, the most intuitive control action is to temporally switch off a machine when it is not in use and switch it back on when new jobs arrive. However, this may become complicated considering the warm-up and cool-down time typically required by the energy-intensive operations. Moreover, frequent switch on and off a machine may reduce its reliability and life cycle. To resolve this issue, we a series of algorithms are developed in this project to optimize the system performance under these operation constraints.

The results obtained from this NSF project are ready to be applied to a wide range of manufacturing systems. Besides the intellectual contributions on the new technological development, the project also provided students the opportunity to apply the theoretical results in industrial environment. Through the development of new course materials and research training for participating graduate students, this project made positive impacts on the human resource development as well.
